element.name: MODS
element.definition: Root element for a MODS record.
element.usageNote: LDL practices require one XML record per file; `<mods>` must always be the root element rather than `<modsCollection>`.

inputGuidance.spreadsheet: The root element will be added automatically during conversion to XML.
inputGuidance.webform: The root element will be added automatically during conversion to XML.
inputGuidance.xml: Use as the root element. An XML file with `<modsCollection>` as the root element wrapping multiple MODS records may be split using XSLT; contact the LSU metadata librarian for assistance.

element.name: Title
element.definition: A word, phrase, character, or group of characters, normally appearing in a resource, that names it or the work contained in it.
element.instruction: Enter the title of the resource. All items must have a title.
element.usageNote: The title should describe the item in basic terms, but should not attempt to supply an exhaustive description. If no title exists, construct one using accepted standards; use “Untitled” only when the resource is explicitly named “Untitled.” Use information provided on or with the original materials if available.
For additional titles, use a type attribute and/or distinguishing displayLabel attribute.

Contents of subelements `<nonSort>`, `<title>`, and `<subTitle>` will be concatenated in display, with a space automatically inserted between NonSort and Title, and a colon and space automatically inserted between Title and Subtitle.
Titles must always appear first in an item's displayed metadata.

The repository will order items within a collection alphabetically by their main title, using the ASCII values of the characters in the title. Capitalization and punctuation will change the filing order. Numbers will file alphabetically as well, meaning a collection of 12 items with titles such as "Photo 1", "Photo 2", etc. will fall in the order Photo 1, Photo 10, Photo 11, Photo 12, Photo 2, Photo 3, Photo 4, Photo 5, Photo 6, Photo 7, Photo 8, Photo 9. To avoid unintended sort order results in your collection, be consistent with the use of capitalization and punctuation, carefully consider how dates are used as portions of titles, and when using numbers in titles, add leading zeros so that all numbers have the same amount of digits (if there are fewer than 10 items, you can use 1-9; if there are between 10-99, use 01-09; if there are 100-999, use 001-099; etc.)

inputGuidance.spreadsheet: XSLT will automatically place "a", "an", "the", and most leading punctuation into `<nonSort>` subelement.

subelement.name: Title
subelement.definition: The core title of the resource.

subelement.name: NonSort
subelement.definition: Any initial article that should not be used for alphabetical arrangement or database searches.
subelement.usageNote: Use for articles or punctuation that fall at the beginning of the title. Do not duplicate the contents of `<nonSort>` within the `<title>` subelement.

subelement.name: SubTitle
subelement.definition: The remainder of title information following the core title.
subelement.usageNote: A colon and space will be inserted automatically in the display, and do not need to be entered.

attribute.name: displayLabel
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, the default label will be used]

element.name: Identifier
element.definition: Contains a unique standard number or code that distinctively identifies a resource.
element.instruction: Enter the local item number or other identifier associated with the physical item.
element.usageNote: The local file name of the content file may be recorded in this field.

The type attribute designates the type of identifer, with the default for local item number or file name as type="local". Select from Standard Identifier Source Codes at http://www.loc.gov/standards/sourcelist/standard-identifier.html.
The Identifier field is repeatable with different display labels and/or types.

attribute.name: displayLabel
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, the default label will be used]

element.name: Place of Origin
element.definition: Name of a place associated with the publication or origin of a resource.
element.instruction: For formally published materials, enter the place of publication as it appears on the resource. For a resource with no formal publication, optionally, enter the place the resource originated.
element.usageNote: Use of Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN) is encouraged.
Places as subjects of a resource are recorded under Subject - Geographic.

inputGuidance.xml: Use the displayLabel attribute at the top level `<originInfo>` element to distinguish between "Publication" and "Origin".

element.name: Publisher
element.definition: The name of the entity that published, printed, distributed, released, issued, or produced the resource.
element.instruction: For a published resource, enter the publisher’s name as it appears on the resource.
element.usageNote: Uploading to the LDL is not considered formal publication; credit to the repository for making the resource available is implied under Source.

element.name: Date
element.definition: Either the date that the resource was published, released, or issued; or, the date of creation of the resource.
element.instruction: For formally published materials, enter the date of publication as a dateIssued element. For unpublished materials, enter the date for the creation of resource as a dateCreated element. Use the W3C date format YYYY-MM-DD for complete dates, or YYYY-MM or YYYY for partial dates (W3CDTF).
element.usageNote: At least one instance of either dateIssued or dateCreated is required. Exactly one date* field should have a keyDate="yes" attribute. For a date range, it is recommended that the start date has the keyDate attribute.
If distinct dates of creation and publication exist for the resource, use both dateCreated and dateIssued. In this case, it is recommended that the publication date has the keyDate attribute
For a date range, repeat the date* field and use the point attributes to mark the start and end point.

When a date is uncertain or supplied, indicate this through the use of the qualifier attribute rather than inserting characters such as "ca.", brackets, or a question mark as part of the field contents.

When only a decade is known, enter a date range for the entire decade and mark the date as questionable. When only a century is known, enter a date range for the entire century and mark the date as questionable. Do not enter "Unknown," "No date," or similar.

inputGuidance.spreadsheet: Follow the formats in the conversion table, which can be converted to properly formatted W3CDTF MODS dates using existing XSLT.
inputGuidance.webform: Enter only a single W3CDTF formatted date as the value of the field. Use the range option with point attributes and/or qualifier attributes to fully qualify a complex date. Repeat date elements as needed to record multiple dates.
inputGuidance.xml: Enter only a single W3CDTF formatted date as the value of the element. Use qualifier attributes to qualify the date(s). Use multiple dateIssued or dateCreated elements to record multiple dates.

element.name: Date Captured
element.definition: The date on which the resource was digitized or a subsequent snapshot was taken.
element.instruction: Enter the date of digitization for the resource in the W3CDTF format YYYY-MM-DD.
element.usageNote: Use a single date only.

element.name: Abstract
element.definition: A summary of the content of the resource.
element.instruction: Enter a summary, abstract, scope and content note, or other description of the resource.
element.usageNote: Incorporate keywords in order to provide additional access points for searching.
It is recommended that different display labels are used if repeating the Abstract field.
element.enrichment: This element provides end users with information about the digital resource that assists them in making a judgment about its likely usefulness, and also provides context, if needed, for controlled vocabulary used in the record.

inputGuidance.spreadsheet: If repeating the field, add a new column with a distinctive header.

attribute.name: displayLabel
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, the default label will be used; other suggested values are "Summary" or "Scope and Content"]

element.name: Note
element.definition: General textual information relating to a resource.
element.instruction: Enter notes pertaining to the content of the resource that do not fit in a more specific field.
element.usageNote: Record each note in a separate Note field.

The type attribute designates the type of note, with the default for general notes about the resource as type="content". Select from MODS list of note types at https://www.loc.gov/standards/mods/mods-notes.html. Other note types present in the LDL include "biographical/historical", "performers", "thesis", "date".
Use this space to transcribe anything handwritten, stamped, or printed on the image, mat, or case.
Include any descriptive information accompanying the item and any pertinent information not represented in other fields.
Notes relating to physical description should be recorded in a Physical Description Note.

inputGuidance.spreadsheet: Add columns as needed; use column headers to specify display label.

attribute.name: type
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, "content" will be used; select from MODS list of note types.]

attribute.name: displayLabel
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, the default label will be used; other suggested values are "Summary" or "Scope and Content"]

element.name: Type of Resource
element.definition: A term that specifies the characteristics and general type of content of the resource.
element.instruction: Select an authorized MODS value characterizing the resource’s format.
element.usageNote: Use all lowercase letters without punctuation.
Use 'collection' attribute to distinguish collection-level records.

inputGuidance.spreadsheet: Use the drop down menu provided.
inputGuidance.webform: Use the drop down menu provided.

element.name: Genre
element.definition: A term or terms that designate a category characterizing a particular style, form, or content, such as artistic, musical, literary composition, etc.
element.instruction: Enter a term for the genre of the resource that characterizes its content.
element.usageNote: Choose applicable genre terms from the Getty Art and Architecture Thesaurus (AAT), particularly terms denoted as "genre". Other vocabularies, including local ones, may be used with consultation from a metadata librarian.
The Genre field should be used to characterize the content of the resource rather than the resource itself or its physical characteristics, which would be Form.

element.name: Form
element.definition: A designation of a particular physical presentation of a resource, including the physical form or medium of material for a resource.
element.instruction: Enter a generic term for the form of the original resource.
element.usageNote: Choose applicable terms from the Getty Art and Architecture Thesaurus (AAT), particularly terms denoted as "...by internal form". Other vocabularies, including local ones, may be used with consultation from a metadata librarian.
The Form field should be used to describe the physical characteristics of the resource rather than its content, which would be Genre.

element.name: Physical Description Note
element.definition: General textual information about the physical description of a resource.
element.instruction: Enter a description of the medium/media used in the creation of the physical resource, or (changing the Type attribute) other details about the physical object not captured in controlled fields.
element.usageNote: The type attribute designates the type of note, with the default usage of this field in the LDL being type="medium". Select from MODS list of note types at http://www.loc.gov/standards/mods/mods-notes.html. Other note types present in the LDL include "condition", "marks", "technique", and "physical details".
Terminology may be drawn from AAT, but this field is not controlled or faceted. Use the Form field to enter controlled vocabulary terms.

attribute.name: type
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, "medium" will be used; other suggested values are "physical details", "condition," or "technique"]

attribute.name: displayLabel
attribute.value: [uncontrolled; if omitted, the value of the type attribute will be used]

element.name: Extent
element.definition: A statement of the number and specific material of the units of the resource that express physical extent.
element.instruction: Enter a statement of size or number and specific material of the units of the resource.
element.usageNote: Typically used to describe the original physical resource.

element.name: Internet Media Type
element.definition: An identification of the electronic format type, or the data representation of the resource.
element.instruction: Select from the controlled list of terms available from the MIME Media Types list.
element.usageNote: The enumerated values cover present LDL standards. Contact a metadata librarian if using file types not listed.
For objects containing multiple file types, use a separate `<internetMediaType>` field for each.

element.name: Digital Origin
element.definition: The method by which a resource achieved digital form.
element.instruction: Select a controlled term from the MODS vocabulary describing the source of the digital file.
element.usageNote: Required for any repository object that has a content file. In other words, this field is not required for compound parent objects, but is required for compound child objects, as well as simple objects.

Most LDL content will be "reformatted digital". Use "digitized other analog" only when the digital resource was created by digitizing an intermediate form other than microform, such as a photocopy, of the original. See MODS User Guide for more on the definitions of values.

element.name: Language
element.definition: A designation of the language in which the content of a resource is expressed.
element.instruction: Enter the authorized text term from ISO 639-2 for the language used within the resource in a `<languageTerm>` field with type="text". Enter the alpha-3 language code from ISO 639-2 for the language used within the resource in a `<languageTerm>` field with type="code".
element.usageNote: For the Code term, use all lowercase letters without punctuation.
For multiple languages present in a resource, repeat the `<language>` wrapper element, each with a pair of `<languageTerm>` subelements for text and code.
The Language field is not recommended for resources that do not have a language component (such as photographs).
"English"/"eng" as a Language value is not to be omitted and/or understood as a default.

inputGuidance.xml: `<language>` is a container element, which should have one or more `<languageTerm>` subelements within it.

subelement.name: Language Term
subelement.definition: Contains the textual or coded form for the language of the content of the resource.
subelement.usageNote: All attributes below are applied to the `<languageTerm>` subelement.

Use the type attribute on the `<languageTerm>` subelement to designate text and code values. The `<languageTerm>` subelement with attribute type="code" must have an authority attribute with the value "iso639-2b".

element.name: Digital Collection
element.definition: The name of the LDL digital collection to which the resource belongs.
element.instruction: Enter the title of the digital collection.
element.usageNote: Use the full title as it appears in the collection level metadata. The value should be consistent throughout the collection.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Digital Collection" should be used on the `<titleInfo>` element.

element.name: Relation
element.definition: The URL of the home page of the LDL digital collection to which the resource belongs.
element.instruction: Enter the URL of the digital collection landing page.
element.usageNote: The format is: http://louisianadigitallibrary.org/islandora/object/[collection_namespace]:collection. The collection_namespace is the institution code (namespace prefix), hyphen, collection code (alias) for the collection.
This value should be consistent throughout the collection.
Enter the URL only; any helper text will cause the MODS record to fail validation.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Relation" should be used on the `<url>` element.

element.name: Repository Collection
element.definition: The name of the repository collection to which the original physical resource belongs.
element.instruction: Enter the title of the repository collection.
element.usageNote: Use this field when the name of the digital collection differs markedly from the repository collection, or when a digital collection is composed of materials from multiple repository collections.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Repository Collection" should be used on the `<titleInfo>` element.

element.name: Repository Collection Guide
element.definition: The URL of a finding aid or other guide for understanding and accessing the repository collection to which the resource belongs.
element.instruction: Enter the URL of the finding aid or repository collection guide.
element.usageNote: Enter the URL only; any helper text will cause the MODS record to fail validation.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Repository Collection Guide" should be used on the `<url>` element.

element.name: Physical Location
element.definition: The institution or repository that holds the resource or where it is available.
element.instruction: Select the name of the institution or repository that holds the physical resource from the locally-controlled list.
element.usageNote: If the physical resource is housed at a different institution from the LDC member institution providing it to the LDL, consult a metadata librarian for guidance.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Physical Location" should be used on the `<physicalLocation>` element.

element.name: OCLC Member Symbol
element.definition: [An encoded reference for] the institution or repository that holds the resource or where it is available.
element.instruction: Select the OCLC Member Symbol of the institution or repository that holds the physical resource from the locally-controlled list.
element.usageNote: If the physical resource is housed at a different institution from the LDC member institution providing it to the LDL, consult a metadata librarian for guidance.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "OCLC Member Symbol" should be used on the `<physicalLocation>` element.

element.name: Institution Web Site
element.definition: Contains the Uniform Resource Location of the resource; an electronic location from which the resource is available.
element.instruction: Select the URL for the home page of the institution or repository that holds the physical resource from the locally-controlled list.
element.usageNote: In the LDL display, this value will be the hyperlinked URL associated with the text in the Physical Location field.
If the physical resource is housed at a different institution from the LDC member institution providing it to the LDL, consult a metadata librarian for guidance.
Enter the URL only; any helper text will cause the MODS record to fail validation.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Institution Web Site" should be used on the `<url>` element.

element.name: Sublocation
element.definition: Department, division, or section of an institution holding a copy of the resource.
element.instruction: Enter the name of the department, buidling, collection, or other sublocation that holds the physical resource as applicable.
element.usageNote: Use names from an institutionally-controlled list as available.

element.name: Shelf Location
element.definition: Shelfmark or other shelving designation that indicates the location identifier for a copy.
element.instruction: Enter shelving information for the physical resource to assist in locating the original.

element.name: Rights
element.definition: Information about restrictions imposed on access to a resource.
element.instruction: Enter the rights statement for accessing the resource.
element.usageNote: Either the legacy "Rights" field or the "Standardized Rights Statement" field is required, with the latter strongly recommended.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Rights" should be used on the `<accessCondition>` element.

element.name: Standardized Rights Statement
element.definition: [A standardized license or statement] about restrictions imposed on access to a resource.
element.instruction: Select the applicable statement from RightsStatement.org; record the statement's URI in the "xlink:href" attribute, and the statement text as the field value.
element.usageNote: Either the legacy "Rights" field or the "Standardized Rights Statement" field is required, with the latter strongly recommended.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Standardized Rights Statement" should be used on the `<accessCondition>` element.

element.name: Contact Information
element.definition: Information provided to users in order to contact the repository about a resource.
element.instruction: Enter contact information for the owning repository.
element.usageNote: Include at least one of an institutional email address or a URL for a dedicated website pertaining to reproduction and reuse.
This field may include other information instructing users how to make a request for reuse or reproduction.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Contact Information" should be used on the `<accessCondition>` element.

element.name: Restriction on Access
element.definition: Information about restrictions imposed on access to a resource.
element.instruction: Enter the terms of any restrictions on access to the resource.
element.usageNote: This may include IP range limitations and/or embargoed materials.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Restriction on Access" should be used on the `<accessCondition>` element.

element.name: Preferred Citation
element.definition: A formatted bibliographic citation for the resource.
element.instruction: Enter a formatted bibliographic citation for the collection or item.

inputGuidance.xml: A displayLabel attribute with value "Preferred Citation" should be used on the `<note>` element.
